This is a replacement oil barrel for the board game "Power Grid" by Friedmann Friese and Rio Grande Games.

This barrel is the same size as the stock piece, so it should integrate seamlessly into your game.
Print in black.  Use the multiply module in Skeinforge to lay it out in a 5x5 grid.  This will give you all the pieces you need to play and a couple extra.
Not required spacial setting, the only thing that i use few times is brim.

Totally obsolete / useless / overkill Thingy for the REAL pedantic Thingiverse users.

UPDATE: Uploaded the Solidworks files.

Yes, you could do this with just a few pieces of wire.

  1. make a cross
  2. measure the distance from a leg to the center cross
  3. measure a distance that should be equal
  4. shift one side of the machine
  5. repeat step 2, 3 and 4 until the distance is the same

Since you will need to do this only once better just use a wire :-) But for some people with extreme size MPCNCs this actually might help them square their machine.The tape measure can be used behind the yellow part.

So the whole idea is to get an equal legged triangle on one side. If all lengths of your machine are the same then you are square. You can check the other 3 sides. They should all be equally legged triangles.

(See hardcore PAINT picture)
AB, BC, CD or AD can be corrected. if your opposite sides are of equal length, than the X and Y dimension are perpendicular to each other.

description.text:
For this week's project, we designed and 3D printed a simple case for Circuit Playground. This bumper and 2-piece strap turns Circuit Playground into a wearable. 3D printed in Ninjaflex filament, the strap is printed flat and wraps nicely around your wrist (or leg?). The bumper bites on the edge of the PCB and holds it in place. On the bottom of the bumper are two slots, where the strap can be inserted into. The straps themselves have extensions on the end, which acts as end stoppers. The two straps snap fit together via holes and a little nub. It's a really simple design and relatively easy to 3D print (as long as you print SLOWLY - 30mm/s).

While designing the bumper and strap in Autodesk Fusion 360, we decided to try out User Parameters - These are special parameters that allow you to quickly and easily update a values. So, instead of editing a sketch and modifying dimensions, you can open up the user Parameters dialog box and input a width or length of the strap. We also added number of holes, and the distance of them. There's lots of other User Parameters we could add (like the overall diameter of the bumper) so we put together a Layer by Layer tutorial to show you how easy it is to setup.

Tutorial Guide - https://learn.adafruit.com/circuit-playground-wearable/overview
Ninjaflex - https://adafruit.com/products/2080
CAD Tutorial - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUCx9MsDHjM
Design Source - http://a360.co/29OSTnu
Circuit Playground CAD Component - http://a360.co/29J7KBB

Hanging lamp designed in the form of a mechanic octopus.

The lamp socket part was designed to fit the brazilian socket standard measures (3.6cm). If you need a different measure to fit a different lamp socket, please, feel free to send me a request for a new size.

A printing bed of 30cm x 20cm is recommended to fit all parts.

The ceiling part is 15cm tall, supports are recommended to print it.

The images feature a model printed in silver PLA.

This one was a bit trickier to assemble than my other models, will have to improve it in the future. I tried to design the claws and tails to just snap in the socket part, but the contact area ended up being too small for that, so you will need to glue them.

I recommend to glue the tails only at the final stage of the process or you won't have much space to work on the lamp socket.

I'm no expert on electronics, but adding a small LED lamp inside the ceiling part would add a bit more drama to the whole thing :)

Hope you enjoy it and please, show me your prints!

Other creations can be found at my site www.creattik-pro.com

A simple yet elegantly designed playing cards deck & box can be made in a few minutes with Trotec's Speedy 400 flexx.

Step 1: Engrave the cards

We've provided the templates for the cards (make sure to set the art-bound of your cards to the same dimensions as your material).

For the remainder cards file, make the art-board small enough for all the cards. Place them in the corner of the board using Trotec's JobControl Software).

The cards should be engraved at 45 power, 100 speed with 1000 PPI/Hz.

To cut the cards use 40 power, 2 speed with 2000 PPI/Hz.

We used Black Pegasus Cover stock 260m 20x26 as our material

Step 1: Engrave the cards Step 1: Engrave the cards Step 2: Cut the cards

To cut the cards, you must find the desired cut speed and power depending on your desired shade of colour.

Ex. if you decrease the speed or increase power, the design will become darker.

Make sure totape the material to the bed to prevent misshaped.

Step 2: Cut the cards Step 2: Cut the cards Step 3: Design of the Box

The attached illustrator file will be the design of the box. We made our cut lines as red with a weight of 0.10 and black for the engraving portion. *All colours must be RGB.

Box material is 1/4" thick sold maple wood

dimensions are 3.5" x 2.5" x 1.5"

Step 3: Design of the Box Step 4: Engrave & Cut Playing Cards Box

Our settings for the design is 55% power and 85% speed on the Trotec 100w Speedy 400 flexx laser with 500 ppi.

Step 4: Engrave & Cut Playing Cards Box Step 4: Engrave & Cut Playing Cards Box Step 5: Making the box

Use the interlocking pieces of the wooden box and glue them together.

Ta Daa! Congratulations, you are now ready to start playing cards!

title: Xiaomi Yi Mount for LS210 V2

description.text:
There are alot of mounts for Xiaomi Yi for the old LS210 and QAV210 frames, but not so many for the newer version of LS210. So I made my own instead.

This is a simple mount with a box holding the camera in place. A small space under the mount is used for a strap to hold the camera firmly down. There's a 4-5 mm gap in the back of the camera box for adding some foam to dampen the vibrations and add resistance when strapping the camera in.

I printed this with PLA 3mm layers, support touching the bed.

UPDATE:
As requested I've added a couple of more angles. The default angle (forgot to mention it) is 25 degrees. The additional ones are 30 and 35 degrees.

In this quick project, students will serve as architects working to design new buildings for a client (you!). To ensure the client is satisfied with the buildings, students must make sure that their buildings satisfy the Critical Design Requirements given a set amount of materials and time.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

The 3D printed parts were designed in Tinkercad. There are 6 pre-made designs included in the Thing Files.
As an extension activity, prompt students to design their own connector pieces to improve their design. See instructions at the end of the lesson.
NGSS
In this quick project, students are given a set amount of materials (connector pieces and straws) and time to create a structure that satisfies the client's critical design requirements.

Time: 20 minutes
Prompt: Using your materials provided, you need to build the TALLEST possible structure that can stand on its own and remain standing while being measured. The building should satisfy the Critical Design Requirements on the Building Design Requirements sheet
  • Hand out Design Requirements Sheet - Building 1
  • (5 minutes) Students Plan & Shop for Materials: 3D Printed connectors, Straws, Scissors
    • During planning, students will “shop” for materials (take the materials they need from the class pile).
    • They can only use what they take, otherwise they will have a small penalty. They will also be penalized for taking too many materials. See grading sheet about excess materials and “re-buying” materials
  • (15 minutes) Students create Building 1. Some Rules:
    • All towers will be measured at the end of the time limit, but you may have your tower measured multiple times throughout the activity.
    • You can rebuild your tower as much as you want, but you get NO extra materials, and whatever is left at the end of the time period is what will be measured
    • ONLY use the materials you select during Step 2. If you run out of materials, you can get more, but you will have a penalty.
    • Your tower must stand ON ITS OWN and remain standing while being measured - no leaning against the wall, taping to the floor, magic, etc.
    • Give your tower a creative name!

Time: 20 minutes
Prompt: Using your materials provided, you need to build the STRONGEST possible structure that can withstand 5 lbs of weight for at least 5 seconds. The building should satisfy the Critical Design Requirements on the Building Design Requirements sheet
  • Hand out Design Requirements Sheet - Building 2
  • (5 minutes) Students Plan & Shop for Materials: 3D Printed connectors, Straws, Scissors
    • During planning, students will “shop” for materials (take the materials they need from the class pile).
    • They can only use what they take, otherwise they will have a small penalty. They will also be penalized for taking too many materials. See grading sheet about excess materials and “re-buying” materials
  • (15 minutes) Students create Building 2. Same Rules as Building 1 (above).

Time: 1 - 2 class sessions
If you have more time or would like to add complexity to this project, you can open up a lot of possibilities by having the students design their own 3D printed connector pieces instead of providing them with pre-made parts. Watch the video & read through the steps below for a quick walkthrough on how to do this
  • Start with a new design or import one of the pre-made STL’s into Tinkercad
    • FYI The pre-made connector pieces were made from cylinders with a 5 mm diameter
  • To make a new connection point, drag a new cylinder onto the workplane
  • Resize the cylinder to a 5 mm diameter
    • Drag the Ruler tool onto the workplane to make this easier
  • Use the arrows to drag your new cylinder into place
    • Use the Align tool to help make this easier
  • Group your new connector together!
  • To make even more complex connectors, copy and paste your new cylinder before grouping and add several new connection points.
  • Once you are finished, select Download for 3D Printing, and choose the STL file format. Import into MakerBot Desktop, and print!
    • Make sure to print with a raft, as there is not much surface area contact with the plate.
  • Once you get to this point, you can take the project in a lot of different directions. Have students design completely different structures (bridges, complex shapes, marble runs, etc), get creative!

• Lay out all of the materials beforehand, as the students will be selecting their materials from the class pile.
  • I did not provide the prompt to the students before this activity, so they all were working with the same time constraints
  • Group formation - I grouped students into groups of 3 at random

• http://www.rogersconnection.com/triangles/ - really great breakdown of strength of structures
  • http://www.ctgclean.com/tech-blog/2012/10/the-strength-and-mystery-of-triangles/
  • https://www.teachengineering.org/lessons/view/cub_trusses_lesson01

Objectives

Students should walk away with knowledge of:

  • Working to satisfy design requirements
  • Working with tight time constraints
  • Importance of teamwork
Audience

This activity can be used for a wide range of grade levels, anywhere from 6th grade through 12th grade. I used this project as an “ice breaker” on the 2nd day of class for my 8th grade Physical Science course.

Subjects
  • Science
  • Engineering
Skills Learned (Standards)

MS-ETS1-1 - http://www.nextgenscience.org/dci-arrangement/ms-ets1-engineering-design

"Students who demonstrate understanding can define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions."

MS-ETS1-2 - http://www.nextgenscience.org/dci-arrangement/ms-ets1-engineering-design

"Students who demonstrate understanding can evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the problem"

Extension Activity: MS-ETS1-3 - http://www.nextgenscience.org/dci-arrangement/ms-ets1-engineering-design

"Students who demonstrate understanding can analyze data from tests to determine similarities and differences among several design solutions to identify the best characteristics of each that can be combined into a new solution to better meet the criteria for success."

Duration

1-2 class periods (3-4 if you want to include the extension activity)

Materials

To prepare for this lesson you will need the following supplies:

  1. Drinking straws (50 per group) - these work great, but are individually wrapped :/
  2. Scissors (1 per group)
  3. Ruler (1 per group)
  4. 3D printed connector pieces (20 - 30 of each type per group) - in Thing Files
    • PRO TIP: If possible, print each connector piece in it's own color
    • Print extras of the Corner Connector file, it’s usually the most popular
Designing a Custom 3D Printed Connector in Tinkercad Rubric and Assessment:
  1. Rubric - If you want to run this as a graded activity, the grading rubric is attached in the Thing Files.
  2. Reflection Questions - (also included in Student Handout in the Thing Files)
    Submit a TYPED reflection on the building and design of your tower design. This paper should be 8-10 sentences (or more) and should include the following information:
    • A description of your final designs
    • Your initial design/plan
    • How did this initial design change as you built your structures?
    • Did you ever start over?
    • The final height of your Building 1? How much weight could your Building 2 hold?
    • What was the hardest part of building your structures?
    • Anything else you learned while building?
    • The title of your paper should include the name of your design
Handouts & Assets:

Included in the Thing Files:

  1. Student Handout
    • Prompt
    • Rules
    • Homework assignment
  2. Building Design Requirements Sheet
  3. Grading Rubric

description.text:
This is a magnetic, self-assembling Dodecahedron sphere. It's built up around 0.375x0.1875in (3/8x3/16in) radially aligned magnetic cylinders. You can find them at K&J Magnetics. (Like so: https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D36DIA)

Each part has 5 snap-inserts which hold the magnet in place and allow it to spin freely around its axis. This means that each magnet will self align to its adjacent magnet and the sphere can self assemble itself when parts are close.

comments.text: This is a really great design!  I'm printing one now.  I used 4x4 mm diametrically magnetized magnets I found on AliExpress, which were much cheaper than the magnets you used (but also less strong).  So far so good, the pieces do stick together but we'll see if the whole structure can stand.
comments.author: doctorjay

comments.text:
Hi, Thanks for sharing this.
Just to clarify... the file contains 2 objects. Are they (as they seem to be) exactly the same? Or is there some slight difference between them?
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text: yes, they should be the same. there needs to be a margin for the magnets to spin freely (and they need to have the correct magnetic axis alignment!) 0.5mm shouldn't make much of a difference.

Easy STOP/START button solution for stopping and starting the 3D print job on octoprint, running on raspberry pi from the printers location. The script can be edited to work on any device with GPIO and is meant to be a baseline for more complicated projects.

The code is very simple, every time the physical button is pressed the server check if there is a printer job running if there is one it stops it otherwise it starts a job that is preselected.

The code that runs this is available on
http://tnorbert.com/simple-stopstart-button-for-octopioctoprint/
or
https://github.com/BoKKeR/STOP-START-button-for-OctoPi-OctoPrint/blob/master/button.py

description.text:
Now updated with some bug fixes and an ISLAND generator - see below

This customizer generates vartiations of fortresses and castles, simple to complex, with simple friendly controls.

If you're new to the Customizer concept, start by hitting the "Open in Customizer" button on the right panel. After you play around with the settings and like what you see, click "Create Thing" to have it generated (takes a while) as an STL file you can download and print.

In this code I'm attempting to combine the best of the two previous generators:
Recursive turrets
Perimiter wall with towers
But instead of 30+ controls, you now have only 9.
This means less specific control, but the ability to explore a large variety quickly.

ISLAND GENERATOR

Play around with the island-random-seed for different formations and sizes, or set it to 0 for no island.
This brilliant addition is courtesy of Torleif whose own generators are mind blowing (seriously, its the real thing). Check it out if you know whats good for you.

title: Flash Forge Creator Pro (2016) X-Axis Support

description.text: Flash Forge Creator Pro (2016) X-Axis Support

Cable support for X axis of the flash forge creator pro.

On mine the exposed wires would rub along the x axis guide rails. I wrapped them in some 10mm corrugated tubing and printed this little support to clip the tubing in to minimize cable stress at the stepper motor. I drilled a small hole and used a screw but it could just as easily be glued on.
The little hole through the clip was a guide hole for a drill bit just in case a cable tie was required however I haven't needed one.

Printed standing on its end. 100% infill. 0.2 layer height. 2 shells in ABS plastic.

description.text:
This is a centrifuge rotor designed to hold 50ml plastic tubes. My application is to spin yeast vials for homebrewing in order to pour off trub from washed samples.

It can be attached to a drill press in order to provide adjustable RPMs. To attach it insert 1/4"-20 threaded rod in to the chuck and then have one nut on top in the rotor and the other nut and washer under the rotor.

Parts required:
3" or longer 1/4"-20 rod stock
2x 1/4"-20 nuts
1x 1/4"-20 large washer

Trotec has designed a beautiful Christmas card (hand made by our staff) that was engraved by our Speedy 300 Laser CO2 Cutter.

Hand drawn snowflakes were later photographed and imported into CorelDraw to be vectorized and engraved onto the card.

A great idea for the holidays!

Step 1: Draw your design

Feel free to draw any design you like, as long as it's a thick marker or pencil on white paper. We ourselves drew snowflakes.

Step 1: Draw your design Step 2: Vectorize your photo

Import your drawing into a vector based software (we used CorelDraw).

Step 2: Vectorize your photo Step 3: Convert to Black and White

If you are using CorelDraw, the steps are to go to Bitmaps > Mode > Black and White. Use the Line Art Method. Decrease the threshold to only see the black snow flakes.

Step 3: Convert to Black and White Step 4: Vectorizie the design

We vectorized the file by clicking on Trace Bitmap, Outline Trace, and we used the Line Art option. Delete after these steps.

Step 4: Vectorizie the design Step 5: Setting options

Right click on the RGB red and left click on no-fill. The red outline should be set at hairline thickness so the laser cuts it.

Step 5: Setting options Step 6: Duplicate the image

Spread the design around (copy and paste).

Step 6: Duplicate the image Step 7: Create a fold line

This will be hairline thickness. Once senr to the laser, decrease the power to 5% with 2 speed.

Step 7: Create a fold line Step 8: Outline and Content

create a red outline box (hairline thickness) to cut out. Add text in black to engrave.

Step 8: Outline and Content Step 9: Send the design laser

Click print. Engraving set at 100 speed and 45 power. Cutting set at 2 speed and 40 power. fold line is 2 speed and 5 power.

Now it's done! Don't forget to send the card to someone special!

title: Fairing Piece with Scoop and Vent

description.text:
A partial box shaped fairing with low profile venturi scoop and louvered trailing vent. Idea is to have this direct air over the cooling fins on an ESC or similar R/C component that gets hot. Should be flush-mounted as the side flanges are intended to anchor down internally. I suspect if it works, it'd work best on an airplane that is moving quickly forward through the air.

Simple .blend file so you can adjust with alterations and set for scale as needed in Blender.

No exact science to this so other adjustments are likely needed. Figuring it should work to some extent following the principle of "duck typing", yet scaling may affect effectiveness - in which case it just looks cool.

My process of modeling the fairing in Blender.

Just a video screen recording of how I go about modeling this. Might be a little long, but I'm in no rush and making adjustments/corrections on the fly.

Trotec lasers offer endless applications and to showcase this, we've made a tie from scratch using the Trotec Speedy 500.

Materials required:

• 2 yards x 1 yard black polyvinyl leather

• Scissors

• Tape

• Ruler

• Pen (or any item that can mark the underside of the material)

Step 1: Design the tie

You may create your own tie outline, but 'we've also included a base outline for your convenience. The red outline should be hairline thickness to cut while black fill is engrave.

Step 2: Cut dimensions

Measure and cut out the size of the tie from the material. Our tie was 28 by 48 inches.Vinyl is a preferred material so are bright colours..

Step 2: Cut dimensions Step 3: cut and engrave

Tape down the material. We set the Speedy 500 CO2 80w laser because of the large bed it offered. We set the speed to 100 and 28 power to 1000ppi for engraving. For cutting we set it to speed 2 and 20 power 1000hz.

Once it's done you can now walk in style with your brand new tie.

description.text:
Pokeball USB Battery Holder. Fits Anker USB lipstick sized USB batteries.

https://www.amazon.com/Anker-PowerCore-Lipstick-Sized-Generation-High-Quality/dp/B005X1Y7I2/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1469043613&sr=8-2&keywords=anker+usb+battery

Should fit original PowerCores. Haven't tested on PowerCore+ but dimensions should work.

Print with supports or use half size and glue together. If printing HIPS you may not need supports at all when printing half size. You should finish with Bondo and spray paint. Cover in bondo, sand aggressively. Spray evenly, polish to a smooth finish.

Suggest using Bondo Spot and Glaze putty to create a smooth surface, and passes of sandpaper from 80 up to 2000.

Supplies:
Bondo #907
Rubber gloves
Masking tape
Rustoleum Apple Red Gloss
Rustoleum Gloss White
Rustoleum Flat Black
High fill spray primer
Superglue or Epoxy
160, 600, 1000, 2000 grit sandpaper.
Meguiar's M105, M205 compounds
Sponge compound applicators or dual action / rotary polisher if you are nuts
Clearcoat for the overachiever
A lot of patience for sanding

Tips for making this:

  1. Make each half at a time. Cover with Bondo Spot and Glaze putty #907. Smooth using rubber gloved fingers. Wait for it to dry, about 15 minutes.
  2. Sand with 160, then 600 grit.
  3. Apply more 907 where you had low spots and missed areas. Wait to dry.
  4. Sand with 160, then 600 grit again. Repeat if necessary. You should have a very smooth ball at this point. Clean sanded areas off with dry cloth.
  5. Shoot with spray primer. Sand with 1000 grit.
  6. Shoot each half with gloss spray paint. I used Rustoleum Gloss Apple Red and Gloss White. Allow to dry 24 hours.
  7. Wet sand with 1000 grit, then 2000 grit. You should have a non glossy appearance. It should look kinda dull. Spray paint again if you had to take out a lot of paint in sanding due to runs, etc. Repeat sanding until smooth (but still dull after sanding). Clean sanded areas off with dry cloth.
  8. Sand interior channel where the USB battery goes. Check fitment.
  9. Glue together using superglue or jbweld / loctite epoxy.
  10. Apply more spot putty and sand to erase the edges.
  11. Mask red and white areas with masking tape. Shoot flat black spray paint. Sand.
  12. Remove masking tape. If overspray, curse loudly.
  13. Using Meguiar's M105 cutting compound and a sponge applicator, polish.
  14. Using Meguiar's M205 polishing compound and sponge, polish. The thing should be ridiculously shiny.
  15. If you are an overachiever, apply clear coat. Sand. Polish.

Edit:
Added a nice render :)
Added some WIP pictures of Bondo covered half.
I'll add more pictures as my paint finishes drying.

author: NickRimmer

description.text: When your camera is too much inclinated, you can't see horizon at the start. This stand solve this problem.

Decided to make a round filament spool holder for the Fabrikator Mini. It's a little heavy on the materials, as the cylinder is fairly wide to allow for easy rotation of the spool. (This one is also designed for a full size 1kg spool, rather than the .5kg spools Hobby King suggests for this machine, and which many of the other spool holders I've found are designed for.) Many of the "square" holders on Thingiverse will use far less plastic as well. Nothing wrong with those designs- I just saw an opportunity to make something a little different & practice design in Tinkercad.

Printed the first copy of this on my Monoprice Maker Select i3, and it came out fairly well. And in a testament to the wonders of digital calipers, it fit like a glove! There is less than 5mm of clearance between the full size 1kg spool and the extruder, so it is a close fit, but it should work fairly well. My only lingering concern is how well it will work with a full spool, and whether or not the weight of a full spool will cause any tipping issues, or if the extruder motor will have trouble with the extra unsprung weight.

Once I get a brand new spool to try out, I'll update this description. For now, I at least know it fits like a dream. Which shocked me, since it was my first draft.

***Update 12 August, 2016: extruder does not appear to struggle with the full sized spool, machine does not tip with full sized spool, but if I push it backwards, the tipping point is not terribly far back. So I printed some support feet found here on Thingiverse, by user drofnas: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1396469

I also imported that design into Tinkercad & cut it down to make matching front feet. They are all a great fit, and the rear feet make the machine feel very stable with a large spool hanging off the back.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aOR9d1Xys07

remixed_from.author: mread
remixed_from.title: Frame mount for Cateye Strada wireless cycle computer.

title: Cateye Micro Wireless Bike Computer Stem & Headset Mounts

description.text:
I have a couple of older Cateye wireless bike computers that didn't come with stem mounts. I saw a couple of models on this site that were close but wouldn't fit. mread's frame mount for the Strada seem the closest. The Strada's mount (and most newer Cateye wireless computers) is different than my Micro Wireless and Cordless 2 (CC-MC100W and CC-CL200) and therefore doesn't fit them. So I started with that one and combined some of the features of hobbyman's harness to better fit and add the unlock lever goodness.

Note that for the stem mount your bar stem needs to be pretty long to allow room to slide the computer down onto the mount. Use 6 in. zip ties to affix the mount to your stem as the 8 in. ties are too wide.

For the headset mount first make sure that you've already tightened your stem bolts to the steerer tube so that you don't have to use the headset cap for compression anymore. you'll need to have enough room on the steerer tube above the stem to fit part of the mount's spacer. You may have to do some spacer gymnastics on your steerer to achieve this. While you're doing that make sure you don't leave any exposed steerer tube above the mount's spacer or you won't be able to tighten the headset cap onto the spacer to hold it tight.

As for printing, I had the best results printing the object at a 45 degree angle with 5-10% support (as columns) and an overhang angle of 80+ degrees and a brim to minimize support cleanup.

This is a liquid filled temperature probe for a kegerator, keezer, or any other refrigerator where you want to track the liquid temp, and not just the air temp inside the fridge (which will swing high and low significantly with compressor cycles).

This uses a very common digital temp probe, the DS18B20, in a waterproofed stainless package. If you're an Arduino person, you know where to find these.

For the liquid tube, I am using a cleaned out White Labs yeast vial. All you home brewers have these laying around everywhere!

First part holds the actual vial, and you can double-side tape it to the wall in your kegerator.

Second part keeps the temp probe suspended in the liquid, so it is not touching the side walls.

I'm using this with a solution of about 50% vodka and water, just to keep it from icing up when the temps are hovering right near freezing.

Please let me know what you think in the comments. I'm not sure about the long-term effects of alcohol on PLA, whether it will dissolve it or not. This is not a food-safe application, remember the alcohol solution is self-contained in the vial strictly to measure temp, and is not consumable.

Included the original SketchUp files as well in case you want to edit. Enjoy!

description.text:
Unsatisfied with the looks of the existing models of the poop emoji aka smiling turd, I made my own from scratch to be as faithful to the original as possible. Eventually the best method proved to actually mimic the process of depositing a long sausage onto a flat surface, by applying the Curve modifier in Blender with a hand-crafted spiral. In a sense, I simulated the process of depositing poop using high-tech. Ah, the joys of technology!

Included is a single unified model, separate files for dual nozzle printing if you want for instance the eyes and mouth in white and the rest in brown, and separate files for printers that can print with more than 2 materials. If you want to print with three materials, combine the ‘dual-mat1’ file (any shitty colour you like) with the ‘multi-mat2’ (eyes and mouth, white) and ‘multi-mat3’ (pupils, black) files.

If you want to print this really large or on a high quality setting, you may want to print the ‘hiPoly’ variations of the model. If a file doesn't have a hiPoly variant, it is identical between the two qualities.

If you print the single model or the two-material model, the inside of the eyes can be coloured with a sharp permanent marker, which is easier than trying to paint them.

A Blender file with the non-merged parts is also available for easier remixing.
If you prefer a model that doesn't have the internal structure, check out sporadic's remix. It prints faster when using a low infill. There are other remixes as well, for instance one where you can print and assemble the parts separately.

Printing should be easy, no rafts or supports required. You may need to force infill across the entire model to avoid that gaps occur at the seams between the ‘sausage’ due to shrinking of the material (especially with ABS).

I did my best to remove self-intersecting volumes, MeshLab still shows a few intersecting faces but it shouldn't cause any problems with any decent slicer.

If you really like this, use the ‘Tip Designer’ button to buy me a beer!

Edit 7/23/16: I suggest using the newer official design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1685622 which has a deeper slot allowing the stepper plug to be threaded through after the T is assembled.

My CT scanner kit arrived without the wire clips. I've converted the CT Scanner wire clip DXF file to STL for those that may not have received the laser cut acrylic wire clips.

Depending on your printer, the clip could be an overly tight fit on the acrylic T. Do not force the wire clip onto the acrylic T. Trim as necessary with an E-Xacto knife (or file, sand, etc) for an easy fit.

title: Gearwork Pegboard for 3D Printed Pin Connectors

description.text: For Thing-A-Day Day 01 I created a pegboard suitable for mounting and testing gear trains and similar, using Tony Buser's fabulous Pin Connector V2 tools as a first experiment. I figured this tool might be useful for the MakerBot Clock Makers project and for educators and students looking to explore basic gear mechanics. This tool will become more useful as people (maybe you? maybe me?) generate tools to lock gears into place for heavier use.

Lasercut using plywood or acrylic. (I'll be using 6mm birch plywood.) The fixed bolt-holes (8mm) are for mounting heavy-use elements such as a crank to start the train moving or the element your train is driving.
You can also use 8mm metric hardware to mount gears -- benefit being the use of nuts to pin elements firmly in place for more complicated/torque-requiring activities.
I will print some pin connectors and share the STLs here along with recommendations for settings for Tony's OpenSCAD tool.

title: Rubber band pistol for House Flies

description.text:
I designed this to combat the fly problem in houses during summer. Its based of the six shot trigger mechanism using nigeljohnson73's design in his Pistol variant here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:603697

I have made the model print in multiple sections joined together with a "dovetail-style" joint, so no gluing is required as everything should "snap" into place (although some extra rubber bands can be used to hold the side plate on). You can down/up scale it to whatever size you want, but for getting rid of flies; bigger is better. This pistol variant shoots loom-sized bands by default size.

You would be surprised how well it works, so try it!

author: JMDesigns

description.text:
SOHO 3d print suggestions
• No support required
• STL files have been test printed at both 0.2mm and 0.1mm layer height
• (Optional) For added print quality use support material for SOHO_Part3
• ABS and PLA plastic filament have been tested successfully

Assembly

  1. Remove printed parts from print bed
  2. Clean up parts as necessary. Some printers may deposit extra material for the first layer that may need to be removed.
  3. Press fit SOHO_Part2 and SOHO_Part3. Use the two pins on the top of SOHO_Part2 as guides. Note, this should be a snug fit.
  4. If available, find a small segment of extra 1.75mm filament. Else skip to Step 9.
  5. Cut the 1.75mm filament into 4 small pieces around 10mm long.
  6. Press these segments into each of the 4 holes on the bottom surface of SOHO_Part1.
  7. Take SOHO_Part2 and match up the holes with the protruding filament in SOHO_Part1.
  8. Press fit SOHO_Part1 and SOHO_Part2 together.
  9. For extra support a dab of super glue can be used between SOHO_Part1 and SOHO_Part2

title: eDOT - Arduino based precision clock and weather station, multipurpose information display
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
eDOT is an Arduino based precision clock and weather station with built in IR remote receiver and automatic brightness adjustment.
The device has been designed to be easily expanded with additional hardware like WIFI module or other.
Thanks to its six 8x8 dot matrix LED display can be used to show many type of information coming either from internal sensor, custom scrolling messages or wireless from the internet (RSS, etc)
It has a very low power consumption, a simple and elegant design that combines glass front face and 3D printed parts for the body.

The project is currently under development and I will be updated

See more on my Youtube page at:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aO3E_kaa-ro
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nWbayQHAAWg

and see also my Youtube channel for more projects:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbIomyFKzBiLHqEb2xv9GHQ

See the project page on Hackster:
https://www.hackster.io/antiElectron/edot-arduino-based-precision-clock-and-weather-station-a76ed0?ref=user&ref_id=110211&offset=14

See eDOTcore page on Hackster:
https://www.hackster.io/antiElectron/edotcore-a-versatile-arduino-board-with-built-in-rtc-7a5b1a?ref=user&ref_id=110211&offset=12

Currently available parts:

  • Left cover with BME280 sensor housing and expansion bay
  • 8x8 dot matrix LED display mounting bracket
  • Foot

Uploaded on 29/07/2016

For the ones that wish to have the circuit 100% ready to go, I'm preparing a custom Arduino board with built in RTC clock (DS3231).
The board is very compact and features:

-2 x I2C ports
-1 x SPI port
-1 x LDR input
-1 x IR sensor input
-3 x 0-5V analog inputs
-6 x digital I/O

The board may be directly supplied up to 12Vdc.

description.text:
This is a dynamic knob and crank builder. Basically, measure the widest (round) part of the knob stem, then measure the flat part, figure out the shrinkage factor for your printer, and select styles, etc.  
This can generate a crank as well. See the Ryobi Drill Press Crank for an example derived using this. The default settings should make a knob for the RepRapDiscount LCD panel controller.  
The RepRapDiscount LCD panel knob depicted was printed in two colors on a single extruder using the M600 Marlin firmware experimental code.  
Version 2, updated 24-October-2013: stem dimensions on RepRapDiscount knob were inaccurate; changed sizing for medium and larger sizes to make a more reasonable size if the stem is small.

To replace a knob, you need three measurements and one calibration datum. You really need a caliper that measures in millimeters. Harbor Freight sells one (in the US) for around $20.

  • Measure the knob stem across the widest part of the stem. This would be the diameter of the stem if there was no flat part.

  • Measure the knob stem from the flat part to the opposing round part. This needs to be accurate.

  • Measure the height of the stem from the point where it would clear any obstacles. If there are screws below where the knob sits you may need to select the stem option or make the penetration less.

  • Print a minimal knob first. This should be a small cube with the same stem fitting properties as a full knob. Use this to test the fit. You should need to push it on rather firmly. Sometimes the first layer is a bit spread out and needs to be pared down with a razor. If the fit just doesn't work, increase the shrinkage (default is 1.06). If it's too loose, decrease the shrinkage value.
    • For larger stems you can drill out a set screw hole.

This is something I created to make my new vacuum bags fit my vacuum cleaner. They were supposed to fit my model but unfortunatly they did not :)
This upload is just for inspiration.
If anyone would want more details, please leave a comment.

Check panel fixators in OpenScad file. Maybe you need to ajust their positions.

For assembly you need:
1) 220V-24V plate
2) Ajustable voltage/current PWM plate
3) LM2596 plate for USB output
4) two bananas socket
5) two many rotation potentiometers (You can use 1 rotate version, but it is not comfortable)
6) A/V-meter.
7) power switch button
8) power cable socket (like in AT/ATX power source)
9) some wires, iron, drill :)

Total costs about 1400RUB or 22 dollars

description.text: A simple air filter for computer case fans. Default settings are for 140mm fan but it's easy to change the parameter for other fan sizes.

Printer:

Da Vinci AiO

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Designed for .4 nozzle. The layer height must be 0.2 to slice properly. I have printed using ABS.

For easier removal from the bed, you can consider printing without glue. I tried with good results. It was still quite tightly attached to the bed though.

Remove from bed very carefully

The mesh tends to stick to the bed very tightly and the single plastic strands tend to break quite easily. Waiting for the bed to cool would be the best idea. But if you're impatient, then try to disconnect it diagonally with the bed cleaning tool and don't rush it.

A mesh like this proved to be very troublesome for most design programs. The amount of intersections for building a solid make most programs crash or get stuck calculating them.

Luckily OpenSCAD is able to do this, even though the rendering takes some minutes.

Then the next challenge was how to slice it properly. If the mesh is in just one level, slicing will result in a million or so small squares. The strength of such mesh would be non-existing.

To get the slicing to produce straight lines, there are two layers for the mesh part. They have 0.2mm height difference but overlap 0.05mm for the solid calculation. This is why the 0.2mm layer height while printing is a must.

This is a replacement for the bed adjustment crank on a Ryobi bench drill press. Mine was broken when I got it at a thrift shop and never fully worked.

The handle needs to be attached to the crank wheel using a single #6-32 1 inch machine screw and a single hex nut. Drop the retainer into the large end of the hollow handle and flip it (if needed) with a screwdriver so the small end is down. Drop a hex nut into the handle and it should fall into the nut trap in the retainer. If not fish with a screwdriver from the bottom.  
Thread the bolt from the bottom through the hole one the crank wheel until the threads engage, then tighten. Retainer should be tight against the crank wheel while the crank handle is free to rotate.  
Optionally drill a hole in the main shaft with a 5/64" bit and tap a #6 machine screw (3/4" should work) against the flat part of the shaft.

title: TIG Monster Claw - TIG Rod Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my TIG Monster Claw! It's purpose is to aid in feeding rod for TIG welding. There are 5 total paths for rods to ride on. I think it's perfect for the n00b all the way to the expert but I'm hoping to get feed back on just how well it helps your TIG life. I'm a n00b but we'll see just how quick this might make me an expert :P

While you're at it, check out the TIG Tungsten Grinder for a rotary tool I got:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905626

The main reason I really needed this was because I type 80-120 WPM and do a lot of security development i.e. my wrists are trashed with carpal tunnal. Add lock picking and all the other precision maneuvers I do with my hands with all my craft/mechanic/design/yard work and running a TIG rod just sucks. So this let me lay the rods in a more natural position so I'm not having to strain as much to guide the rod where I need it especially while keeping it consistent and straight. I was gonna design a much more hoaky contraption but then I thought about the claws and they seem to be perfect!

This claw really only works on the middle finger which was a bonus convenience. You can use your ring finger but it's not as functional IMO. So let the hand gestures roll and now you've got a legitimate excuse to flip the bird, cuz you're just TIG'in!

I demonstrate the various angles that can be used in this Youtube video and you can see the various rod angles I used in CAD to cut the paths out in some of the thumbnails.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xa1KH_aA9d0

The rod paths work perfectly for a 1/8 rod with my large finger scaling for prints I recommend below. There are rod guide paths in each cut that accommodate said 1/8, and then a separate rod path logically aligned that accommodates pretty much any smaller rod you could imagine but hey prove me wrong, and edit the .blend file if you'd like ;)

When printing, I set the model to scale up 1.08 which fits perfectly on a large BSX TIG glove that is a little fatter than my fingers need. Scaled at 1.00, it fits my bare fingers perfectly but who wants to TIG bare handed? For the larger meat hooks out there, I recommend a 1.2 or higher scale.

I recommend 3mm walls minimum and 40% infill minimum. I also use ABS and since that's what most TIG torches are made out of (from what I believe is true...?) and it's about the best melting point you'll get, but feel free to test out those fancy metal filaments and if you do, post a pic!
I print this thing slow too, but slower is better and is kinda fast for the sharp corners and small islands.

The model that can be downloaded is a left handed only model, and must be used on the middle finger unless you want cramps but feel free to experiment! To print a right handed claw, just mirror the image usually on the X axis.

My original model was meant as a Halloween costume piece and you can now find the original Monster Claw here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1684638

Special credit go to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1070477
The key piece to this was based on the Jurassic Park raptor claw which was re-imagined into CAD thanks to kvrtiska!
Who knew 65 million years later, the raptor claw would still prove a useful precision killing tool!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962185
This model provided the base for the finger cover which I used to build out a full on glove for other purposes which I'll upload later. Thanks petergross3!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Infill:

40

Notes:

Place these claws upside down as in the backside of the claw, not the tip, goes to the platform. The tip points straight up, and honestly I set a slight angle upwards so just the backside of the finger plate is sitting on the plate while the rest angles slightly upwards.

The top side is the least functional part and with good support and print speed will come out pretty nice looking. If you want it perfect, then you've hopefully printed 3d a few times and know how to make that happen since it requires some clean up too ;)

You can try printing on the sides but my original models without guide paths (and when I was printing too hot and too fast) came out bad. Slow down and it might turn out fantastic!

I recommend 3mm walls to make this tough and more heat resistant.

I recommend .5mm spacing on your supports to make it sturdy and take out the spaghetti which usually occurs if you print too fast, print too hot, or don't build good support on small detailed parts that require detail all around. 20-30 print speeds with 1.08 up scale to the model before printing gives great results for a TIG Monster Finger going on a Large size glove that's a bit loose on a Large size wearer with thin fingers. Upscale to 1.20 or higher for those larger meat hooks.

comments.text: I think this is great thinking, I started TIG about a year ago so I'm past it but im still gonna try em. My kid can use em too!
comments.author: fozzybear

comments.text:
Ha rock on and appreciate the kudos :) You won't use it all the time but it does come in handy. I'd say it helped me learn to feed rod without it too because I have no issues feeding anymore with or without.
I found it most useful for long runs and if my hands were shaky. The only time I ever had a bit of melting which usually isn't much but it does get on the rod which needs to be cleaned off, was when I was about 1" away at 120A or more. Pretty rare but it's likely to happen when you're that close. But if you're getting in that close, most people would just use their hands; with gloves I'd hope ;)
Have fun TIG'in and teachin the kid to do it too! I only wish I learned earlier in life :)
comments.author: fozzybear

comments.text: I Tig weld for a living and would rather feel the rod in my fingers. I've developed a way of feeding the rod by laying it in between my pointer and middle finger and grip and feed with just the motion of my thumb. Sometimes double grip and feed with my 2 fingers as well for lots of filler. Just thought I'd say what works for me. But if your claw works for you then by all means use it. The more comfortable your are when welding the better work you do
comments.author: jheberer

comments.text: I found this mostly useful for long runs, not short stuff so much only because it's an extra step. If I'm every shaky it really does help keep the rod still too since it's a solid object, not impressionable flesh/gloves. The sliding action for the rod is way smoother than gloves could offer too.

I can see that it can work for beginners. But for us, it will not last. Since we are using temprates from 150 to 400ºC (302-752 degrees Fahrenheit) in preheat before we start the TIG pistol. Much of this reason is for and retaining the mechanical use such as strength, etc.
But the idea is good.
But pushing a TIG thread is very easy then: P use index finger, thumb little finger and ring finger;)

title: ROBOX universal reel holder (smart reel) V1.1 slightly angled arm with smart connection strain relief and working eject button

description.text:
I wanted a universal reel holder that attached to my Robox smart reel connector, I didn't want a stand alone reel holder at the side of the machine, so I remixed clicky's smart reel hub and made one that still allows you to use the eject button (by pushing the arm in)

The reel holder holds full size aftermarket filament reels or the mini sample reel.

V1.0 Basic reel holder (straight) with mini reel (to hold sample filaments)

V1.1 Reel arm Slightly angled (towards machine) to allow smoother filament flow (less drag) The smart connector now has 4 reinforcements attached that slide in to the grooves on the robox to take some of the reel weight reducing the stess on the smart reel connector, also added a mini reel for test samples or spare bits of filament.

scroll down for video

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

low

Infill:

20

Notes:

I used ABS with 20% infil on draft quality cleaned up with dremel as slot was a little small and stuck the parts with acetone

The Next revision will have pieces fitting in the the grooves on the lower half, just to give it a little more support depending on the weight of the reel. The Cone attached to the smart reel adaptor with acetone. push reel holder through, then acetone the button piece in place. Button connection piece in place.

comments.text: Is there any reason that the cone needs to be separate from the main part?  I printed all the parts today, and was a bit disappointed to see that I had to glue the cone onto the robox adaptor.
comments.author: nebbian

comments.text: No particular reason, It was just quicker to print it laid on the flattest side rather than have supports the other way, it was easy enough to acetone/glue together though depending what filament your using and its still very strong. The new V1.1 file is easier to print without the cone as it has the 4 support legs to take some of the reels weight, its also slightly angled towards the printer to allow filament to run a little smoother.

description.text: This is a throat plate for a table router insert. I believe the insert I have is from Sears, but I'm not 100% sure. I think it's a standard size, as it works in my friends Rockler insert also. I had a hell of a time locating one, and when I did they were stupidly expensive for a small disc of plastic. So I designed this one. I just printed a bunch. Whenever I use a new bit I can just run the bit slowly through the plate to get an exact cut at 0 clearance. I was worried that the heat would melt the plastic, but I haven't had a problem yet and I only print in PLA.

This is a Remix of Comfortable Leatherman Wave belt holster by WaveSupportApparatus.

Mostly the changes are of a cosmetic nature i.e. I've tarted it up a bit by rounding some of the hard edges. I've also engraved the words " Leatherman Wave" on the back to avoid confusion, in the unlikely event that someone produces a near identical holster design for a different model from the Leatherman range :)
The only changes I've made to its function have been to realign the belt hole so the holster sits at 90° to the belt rather than at a slight tilt.
I've also removed the cut-outs at the bottom as i don't intend to use the lanyard port .

Printing Tips:
No support structures needed.
If u want the text to come out nice and crisp i recommend thin layers and a slow print speed. The settings i used were 0.15mm layer thickness at a print speed of 25 mm/s. and the text came out looking pretty sweet though i say it my self ;)

title: Auto level probe E3D V6 zero x y offset
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Once I added a glass plate to my heated bed I lost the use of my inductive probe, which I wasn't the biggest fan of to begin with. With no z probe I became pretty good at leveling my bed manually and quickly but would always seem to have one or two spots that were just not quite perfect usually around 0.1 - 0.15 mm different from the rest of the bed. Since my printer kit came with an extra end stop I decided to try to put it to use as a removable Z-Level probe and use z correction to try and get the last little distortion out of my bed.

I designed this to easily slide on and off the heater block of an E3D V6 hotend. Once this is one the switch is positioned directly below the nozzle with a z height of around 15 mm. I did add a small bend to the switch lever to give myself a few more mm of clearance from the bed.

I'm using Repeiter Frimware with the probe mounted and bed heated, I can quickly verify my z offset and run an auto level (g32 s2) and z correction (g33 s2). Once this is complete I like to run a bed height map to check my z correction. As long as everything looks good I can slide the z-probe off and turn on my hotend and get ready to print.

Once this is done there should be no reason to run again unless a change is made to the printer that would effect the bed level.

I am seeing a consistent repeatable trigger height down to 0.01 mm with no deviation.

Printer:

FolgerTech Kossel Rev B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10-20%

description.text:
I tweaked the fan mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104688 I love it but added some usefull mods:
-Easy mount without fully unscrew the extruder screws.
-Added a housing for the nut M3
-Added a little more gap between mobile bracket. *5/Dec/2013 Added link to more compatible fan ducts. *27/Nov/2013 Added a beter fan duct for my J-head MKV (duct1.stl)
See pictures: PLA position (cold PLA and HotEnd) and ABS position (cold HotEnd) compatible also with these fan ducts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:196463 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137673 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104688

author: villamany

title: Anet A8 Hold Down Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are mounting bracket for Anet A8 and A6 printers. Their purpose is to hold down and stabilize the printer base so it doesn't flex while printing or come out of alignment when moved.

Print four brackets, one to hold down each end of the threaded rods as shown in photo. IMPORTANT: To work correctly the brackets need to hold the printer tightly to the mounting surface, so be sure to put a small piece of duct tape on the inside of the bracket to provide a tighter grip against the threaded rods and prevent slipping.

For best results the printer should be mounted to a rigid stable surface. A sheet of 3/4 inch or 19mm particle board, mdf or plywood should work well. Be sure to use a good quality material, especially for plywood, so it doesn't warp. If you don't need portability you can mount it directly to a sturdy table or work bench. Three files are included:

hold_down_bracket.stl - This is the original version and is designed to fit the Anet A8. I've had the same set of these on an A8 printer for two years now and they're still going strong.

hold_down_bracket_a6.stl - DO NOT USE. This is the first version for the A6, it was designed based on comments and feedback, and is for historical purposes only. Use the updated version 2 for the A6.

Hold Down Bracket A6 -v2.stl - Updated version 2 for the A6. This one is modified from the original, based on comments and feedback. Note that I do not have an A6 to test this, so please let me know how it works.

comments.text:

comments.text: It depends on your print. If you're printing something tall, with a lot of detail, and/or higher speeds, you should definitely see a difference. On an easy print it may not be noticeable. The other advantages are that you can move the printer without throwing it out of alignment, and you will not need to level the bed as often.

title: Measuringclock holder at the side for K8200

description.text:
Made a measuringclock holder but that you can keep constantly on your 3d printer. I made this for my limit measuringclock.
Its diamater for the measuringclock is 54,2 cm
I also included the files for sketchup so you can change the holes etc if you like. If you chance it and put it on thingiverse use my name please thank you!

To make this you wil need:
2x M5x60 (with nuts)
4x M5x15 (with nuts)
1x M5 threath tapping
1x M3 threath tapping
1x 5,5 drill Instructions:
Print all the 5 pieces
remove the plastic piece with the screw thats on the microswitch.
remove the 2 screw thats hold the plastic between the 2 metal plates (the 2 on the bottem)
go with the 5,5 drill through the 2 holes at the bottem of the metal plate and the plastic inbetween ( they need to be bigger if you use m5x60)
put the holder frame on it ( its possible you need to file it a little but it need to be tight)
put the screws in and the nuts on it and tighten.
use the m5 threath tapping on the 4 holes of the holder frame and on the 4 holes of the holder for the measuring clock
put the measuring clock between the holderframe and screw in the 4 m5 bolts and secure with nuts.
mount the block_measuringclock and put in the spacer for the microswitch and your done!

title: Anet A8 Improved X-belt Tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This x-belt tensioner works with the original right side bearing block that came with the printer, so you do not need to print a new one. It also tightens against the x-axis rods instead of the right bearing block. This is to prevent binding along the z-axis when the x-belt is tightened.

Be sure to see the readme.txt file for more information on building and installing.

comments.text: How much does this improve print quality? I have already assembled the printer and have been printing for a while. Does the belt stretch and need periodic tensioning to keep the quality the same?
comments.author: Toohardy

comments.text: Yes, the belt will stretch over time. You get the best print quality when the belt tension is set correctly, not too loose or too tight, and this tensioner makes it much easier to adjust. Also, with the original configuration, tightening the x-belt will squeeze the z-axis rails toward each other which may cause binding. This tensioner eliminates that problem by putting the tension on the ends of the x-axis rods instead of the right z-axis bearing block. You can google for details on setting the correct belt tension.

description.text:
This Y-belt tensioner is designed to keep the belt pulley in the same position as the original non-adjusting mounting bracket, in order to maintain the correct geometry along the Y axis. There are two adjusting screws to allow proper alignment of the belt and prevent lateral movement. Printing this with a brim is recommended.

See this link for a pad, designed by ClydeFrog04, that fits under this tensioner and protects the acrylic from being marred by the screws: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073723

THERE IS AN UPDATED FILE COMING SOON
Therefore I recommend you wait until Version 3 is available until you print, the next one will be more compact and better polished.

A simple modification of Pordrack's Pokedex designed to easily slide a Nexus 6p in an out the top. Has a hole for the fingerprint sensor on back as well as speaker and charge port on bottom. Cannon access lock/volume buttons in case.

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

10%
Download and print both files named VERSION 3.0 ... (body and flap). Use BBQ skewer or similar as hinge rod.
